quizzes.question:
Fill in the blanks to turn the string uppercase.
[!raw!]
a = "Spam"
b = a.{0}()
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]String Functions[/h1]

Python contains many useful built-in functions and methods to accomplish common tasks. 
[b]join[/b] - joins a list of strings with another string as a separator. 
[b]replace[/b] - replaces one substring in a string with another.
[b]startswith [/b]and [b]endswith -[/b] determine if there is a substring at the start and end of a string, respectively. 
To change the case of a string, you can use [b]lower [/b]and [b]upper[/b].
The method [b]split [/b]is the opposite of [b]join[/b],[b] [/b]turning a string with a certain separator into a list.
[b]Some examples:[/b] [code format="py" codeId="377"]print(", ".[b]join[/b](["spam", "eggs", "ham"]))
#prints "spam, eggs, ham"

print("Hello ME".[b]replace[/b]("ME", "world"))
#prints "Hello world"

print("This is a sentence.".[b]startswith[/b]("This"))
# prints "True"

print("This is a sentence.".[b]endswith[/b]("sentence."))
# prints "True"

print("This is a sentence.".[b]upper[/b]())
# prints "THIS IS A SENTENCE."

print("AN ALL CAPS SENTENCE".[b]lower[/b]())
#prints "an all caps sentence"

print("spam, eggs, ham".[b]split[/b](", "))
#prints "['spam', 'eggs', 'ham']"[/code]

quizzes.question:
What is the result of this code?
a=min([sum([11, 22]), max(abs(-30), 2)])
print(a)
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]Numeric Functions[/h1]

To find the maximum or minimum of some numbers or a list, you can use [b]max [/b]or [b]min[/b].
To find the distance of a number from zero (its absolute value), use [b]abs[/b].
To round a number to a certain number of decimal places, use [b]round[/b].
To find the total of a list, use [b]sum[/b].
[b]Some examples:[/b] [code format="py" codeId="378"]print([b]min[/b](1, 2, 3, 4, 0, 2, 1))
print([b]max[/b]([1, 4, 9, 2, 5, 6, 8]))
print([b]abs[/b](-99))
print([b]abs[/b](42))
print([b]sum[/b]([1, 2, 3, 4, 5]))[/code]
[b]Result:[/b] [code format="raw" ]>>>
0
9
99
42
15
>>>[/code]

[h1]List Functions[/h1]

Often used in conditional statements, [b]all [/b]and [b]any[/b] take a list as an argument, and return [b]True[/b] if all or any (respectively) of their arguments evaluate to [b]True [/b](and [b]False[/b] otherwise). 
The function [b]enumerate [/b]can be used to iterate through the values and indices of a list simultaneously.
[b]Example:[/b] [code format="py" codeId="379"]nums = [55, 44, 33, 22, 11]

if [b]all[/b]([i > 5 for i in nums]):
   print("All larger than 5")

if [b]any[/b]([i % 2 == 0 for i in nums]):
   print("At least one is even")

for v in [b]enumerate[/b](nums):
   print(v)[/code]
[b]Result:[/b] [code format="raw" ]>>>
All larger than 5
At least one is even
(0, 55)
(1, 44)
(2, 33)
(3, 22)
(4, 11)
>>>[/code]
